title: 109_s707
content: The "PREEMIE Act" aims to reduce preterm labor and delivery rates, establish evidence-based care standards for at-risk pregnant women and preterm infants, and decrease infant mortality and disabilities related to prematurity through research. The "PREEMIE Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to expand CDC research on preterm labor, delivery, and infant mortality. The Secretary will conduct studies on the relationship between prematurity, birth defects, and developmental disabilities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit reports to Congress every 2 years on studies related to preterm birth. Systems will be established to collect maternal-infant information to track pregnancy outcomes and prevent preterm birth. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will review existing tools and measures to include information on risk factors for low birth weight and preterm birth. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011 for this purpose. Additionally, $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007 through 2011 for the implementation of this section, excluding subsection (c). SEC. 4. PUBLIC AND HEALTH CARE PROVIDER EDUCATION AND SUPPORT SERVICES. Part P of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section 399Q for public and health care provider education and support services. The Secretary may conduct demonstration projects to improve information on prematurity for health professionals and the public, including education on preterm labor signs, infection screening and treatment, counseling on weight and nutrition. The Secretary may conduct programs to improve prenatal care, smoking cessation, stress management, and nutrition counseling. Additionally, there are programs to enhance treatment for premature babies and support families with infants in neonatal intensive care units. Other programs may be implemented as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 to carry out the specified purposes. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY COORDINATING COUNCIL ON PREMATURITY AND LOW BIRTHWEIGHT. The purpose of this section is to promote research and collaboration within the Department of Health and Human Services to reduce prematurity and low birthweight. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish an Interagency Coordinating Council on Prematurity and Low Birthweight to achieve this goal. The Council will be composed of representatives from various agencies and will report annually on related activities to the Secretary and Congress. The Interagency Coordinating Council on Prematurity and Low Birthweight will oversee the implementation of activities to reduce prematurity and low birthweight as determined by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Surgeon General's Conference on Preterm Birth is established. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene a conference on preterm birth within a year of this Act. The conference aims to raise awareness of preterm birth as a significant public health issue, review relevant reports, and establish an agenda for identifying and treating causes and risk factors. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress and the public on the agenda for identifying and treating causes and risk factors for preterm labor and delivery. $125,000 is authorized for carrying out this section. The effective date of certain Head Start regulations in the Code of Federal Regulations is delayed until June 30, 2007, or 60 days after the enactment of a statute authorizing appropriations for fiscal year 2007 for the Head Start Act.
